history.content: It really doesn't! It's way more about the skills and experience than the name of the major! In fact, some even think data science is more impressive than plain CS because it's both CS + Statistics. Sometimes, while talking to a recruiter, I say I'm studying data science and computer science since many of my classes are CS (I don't say majoring, I just say studying). With just a data science major & a relatively low gpa (that I omitted on my resume), I am still able to get interviews with many top companies (Google, Amazon, Apple, Airbnb, Visa, Dropbox, Disney & more) for SWE!

It really doesn't! It's way more about the skills and experience than the name of the major! In fact, some even think data science is more impressive than plain CS because it's both CS + Statistics. Sometimes, while talking to a recruiter, I say I'm studying data science and computer science since many of my classes are CS.

children.subject: not in my experience! as long as u have programming languages + cs projects + cs classes on your resume you are fine! you can always throw in the word computer science somewhere on your resume
@student answerer, you're a CS major too so it doesn't count really..
OP here: is it harder to get interviews?

Ah, I was in your shoes too last year, and I went through SO much stress trying to declare. Thinking back, it sucks that I had to do that because it was so bad for my mental health & was completely unnecessary. I wish I knew earlier that data science is a great alternative that doesn't rely on getting the 3.3 GPA in classes where the grades are mainly dependent on exams (I am a terrible test taker due to anxiety/mental breakdowns). Just because you are unable to get the grades needed to declare CS truly DOES NOT mean that you are not cut out for a career in software engineering or any computer science-related field. I learned that I actually had a lot to contribute in CS organizations on campus or in internships, often outperforming my peers even though they were declared (they did better grade-wise in those classes). It sucks that grades are so often not aligned with learning and growth form a class and that that's how entrance into a major is being determined.

With a data science major, you are given some flexibility with upper-divs, you can take classes from different disciplines for your domain emphasis which is pretty cool! I got into 188, 169, 170 so far. I'm not into low-level stuff so I haven't tried to get into the 160 series, etc but yeah it's not the end of the world - you can still have decent success of getting into some classes. There's a new ML class offered by DS department so you don't have to try to get into 189. General SWE really requires just 61b and possibly 170 for interviews; everything else is more specific to what you want to do!
Good luck btw! do your best on today's finals & don't worry about the outcome <3

@student answer, OP here again. Thanks so much for your reply. Gives me a lot of hope. I'll continue to leetcode hard and make personal projects. I'm a sophomore and today's the day of CS70/61B final. These past couple of weeks I've been really depressed and had a few mental breakdowns because I don't think I'll be able to declare. Your experiences definitely help. 

What CS upper div classes were you able to take? And which ones do you think are most essential for SWE?
